Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Ages for Red Giants, New Insights into the Star Formation History of the Milky Way
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this collaborative award, the PIs will determine stellar ages to within 20% using Kepler and CoRoT asteroseismic data, and high-resolution spectra of more than 10,000 red giant branch (RGB) stars. The investigators plan to capitalize on the fact that if the mass and composition of an RGB star can be measured, then the age of the star can be determined accurately because of the swiftness of evolution after the main sequence. Asteroseismological data provides information on RGB pulsation amplitudes, which are combined with metallicity information from spectroscopy and photometry in order to derive the stars? ages. The improved stellar ages are needed to constrain models of star formation and galactic evolution.

The proposal has stated broader impacts in that it will help train a graduate student, some undergraduate students. Also, the work will be relevant to stellar modeling as well as well as Galactic modeling, and the investigators will produce a catalog of red giants with ages, stellar parameters and chemical abundances.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Stars with lifetimes of billions of years provide a "fossil record" of the Milky Way. By measuring the ages and surface compositions of stars, we can trace the star formation history and the enrichment of the Galaxy in the chemical elements. However, ages for stars are hard to measure. One technique is to determine the mass of a star that has exhausted all the hydrogen fuel in its center (a red giant) and use the knowledge from theoretical calculations about how long it takes a star with a certain mass and composition to burn out. Higher mass stars burn through their fuel more quickly than lower mass stars, as a result of their higher energy output. For stars with masses less than 80% of the mass of the Sun, their lifetimes are long enough that essentially all of them that have been born throughout the history of the Galaxy have survived until the present day.

In this project, we measured the composition using spectra from the APOGEE infrared spectrograph, part of the Sloan Digital Sky Survey III (see illustration). To measure the mass, we used asteroseismology, which is the study of the waves that move through stars. In the outer parts of stars, these waves are actually sound waves that can evocatively be described as ringing the star like a bell  The motions of these waves cause a star’s brightness to change by small amounts, and thus the frequency of these waves can be measured by studying the lightcurves of red giant stars. The Kepler satellite, in addition to studying many Sun-like stars looking for transiting planets, also measured the brightnesses over many years of thousands of red giants. The favorite frequencies of waves in different stars have been measured by members of the Kepler Asteroseismic Science Consortium. While much can be learned about the insides of stars from these data, we took advantage of the fact that how long and at what speed waves can move through the star depends on the star’s density and therefore its mass.

Using these data, we have published several papers. We produced a catalog of compositions, masses and radii for ~2000 red giants in the Kepler field as well as accurate measurements of distance and the amount of dust obscuring these stars. Of particular interest were two kinds of stars whose chemistry indicates that they formed early in the Galaxy's history: 1) ones with very little heavy elements in their atmospheres, which implies that they formed before the Milky Way's gas was polluted by many supernovae and 2) ones with large amounts of oxygen, silicon, magnesium and calcium compared to iron. For the first type of stars, we compared the masses determined from asteroseismology with the masses expected based on other work on the ages of these type of stars. We found that the current equations used in asteroseismology systematically overestimated the masses of these stars by a small amount (~10-20%). We are working to improve the equations. For the second type of star, we found a small fraction (~14%) of these stars had masses that suggested that their ages were quite young, at odds with their chemistry. Possible origins for these stars include 1) migration from a distant part of the Galaxy, where the gas had a different chemical history to the solar neighborhood and 2) transfer of some mass from a companion star, raising the star's mass above its initial mass.

To understand whether the first explanation is a possibility, we need to know how often companion stars transfer mass. Current estimates predict that the rate is not enough to explain the 14% of stars where chemistry and mass disagree. As a result of the work from this grant, we now have a better way of measuring this frequency.
